revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox radio station |name = "Cherry Ripe" |image = {{Listen |filename = Cherry Ripe (number station).ogg |title = Cherry Ripe |description = }} |area = [[Humpty Doo]], [[Australia]] |frequency = Several shortwave frequencies between 18.864 and 21.866 [[MHz]] |format = [[Numbers station]] |language = [[English language|English]] |affiliations = [[Royal Air Force]] (Speculated) |owner = [[MI6]] (Speculated) |sister_stations = [[Lincolnshire Poacher (numbers station)|Lincolnshire Poacher]] }} '''Cherry Ripe''' is the nickname of a discontinued [[shortwave]] [[numbers station]] that used several bars from the English [[folk song]] "[[Cherry Ripe (song)|Cherry Ripe]]" as an [[interval signal]]. The station was believed to be operated by the British [[Secret Intelligence Service]] and to have emanated from Australia. It was thought to have previously broadcast from [[Guam]]. It consisted of an electronically synthesised English-accented female voice reading groups of five numbers, e.g. "3-5-7-6-1". The final number in each group was spoken at a higher pitch. It is likely that the station was used to communicate messages to undercover agents operating in other countries, to be decoded using a [[one-time pad]]. Cherry Ripe had a more famous and much more active Middle-Eastern cousin, the [[Lincolnshire Poacher (numbers station)|Lincolnshire Poacher]], which also used several bars from the English folk song of the same name as its interval signal.{{cite web|url=http://www.spynumbers.com/profiles/index.html?ENIGMA=E3 |title=Spy Number Station Profile |website=Spynumbers.com |date= |accessdate=2016-08-17}} The Lincolnshire Poacher had long been suspected as being operated by Britain and had been detected as emanating from [[Royal Air Force|RAF]] [[RAF Akrotiri|Akrotiri]] on [[Cyprus]]. Apart from the interval signal, the format and voice of the two stations was identical, though as of July 2008 the Lincolnshire Poacher appears to no longer be active. In September 2009, Cherry Ripe moved their transmitter to [[Humpty Doo]], Australia. {{cite web|url=http://www.simonmason.karoo.net/page14.html |title=E3 Lincolnshire Poacher |website=Simonmason.karoo.net |date=1988-12-21 |accessdate=2016-08-17}} In December 2009 Cherry Ripe also went off the air.{{cite web|url=http://www.cvni.net/radio/nsnl/nsnl147/nsnl147vs.html |title=NSNL 147 - Voice stations |website=Cvni.net |date= |accessdate=2016-08-17}} ==Schedule== This schedule was accurate as of January 2006. The ancient '''Diocese of Philae''' was a [[Episcopal see|Christian see]] in [[Philae]], [[Egypt]].
==List of Bishops== *[[Macedonius of Philae|Makedonios]], c. 346 *[[Mark of Philae|Mark]], c. 350s, banished to the [[Siwa Oasis]] by the [[Arianism|Arian]] archbishop [[George of Cappadocia]] *[[Isaiah of Philae|Isaiah]], c. 368 *[[Psoulousia of Philae|Psoulousia]], c. 385 *''Unknown?'' *[[Daniel of Philae|Danielios]], c. 450 *''Unknown?'' *[[Theodore of Philae|Theodoros]], c. 520 ‚Äì after 577 (established church within the [[Philae|Temple of Isis]]) *''Unknown?'' *[[Pousi of Philae|Pousi]]
==References== Dijkstra, J. Harm F.: [http://dissertations.ub.rug.nl/FILES/faculties/theology/2005/j.h.f.dijkstra/pt1/c2.pdf Religious encounters on the southern Egyptian frontier in Late Antiquity (AD 298-642)].<!--accessed 22 June 2009-->

{{Infobox film | name = Drexciya (2010) | image = | caption = | director = [[Akosua Adoma Owusu]] | producer = [http://obibinipictures.com Obibini Pictures, LLC] | writer = | starring = | distributor = | released = {{Film date|2010|11|11|Studio Museum at Harlem}} | runtime = 12 minutes | country = [[Ghana]] | language = | budget = | gross = | screenplay = | cinematography = Dustin Thompson
Akosua Adoma Owusu | editing = Dustin Thompson | music = }} '''''Drexciya''''' is a [[Ghana]]ian 2010 short documentary film. == Synopsis == '''''Drexciya''''' is a Ghanaian 2010 short documentary film, produced by Obibini Pictures and directed by [[Akosua Adoma Owusu]]. ''Drexciya'' portrays an abandoned public swimming facility located in Accra, Ghana set on the Riviera. The Riviera at one time was an upscale development, consisting of luxury high-rises and five star hotels. Since the 1970s, the Riviera has fallen into a disheveled state. This short documentary was inspired by afro-futurist myths propagated by the underground Detroit-based band [[Drexciya]]. They suggest that Drexciya is a mythical underwater subcontinent populated by the unborn children of African women thrown overboard during the Trans-Atlantic slave trade. These children have adapted and evolved to breathe underwater. == Awards == * T√°nger 2011 * Menci√≥n Especial FCAT 2011 * Guanajuato International Film Festival 2011 == References == {{RefFCAT|725}} [[Category:2010s documentary films]] [[Category:Ghanaian documentary films]] [[Category:Short documentary films]] [[Category:Ghanaian films]] {{Ghana-film-stub}} {{short-documentary-film-stub}} [[Category:2010 short films]]

Rabee Zureikat | music = Aziz Maraqa | cinematography = Hazim Bitar | editing = Hazim Bitar | studio = Tashkeel Films | distributor = Hazim Bitar
(JO) | released = {{Film date|df=y|2011|6|29|Jordan}} | runtime = 80 minutes | country = [[Jordan]] | language = Arabic
English Subtitles }} '''''Fish Above Sea Level''''' is an upcoming drama film directed and written by [[Hazim Bitar]]. Leading Jordanian film critic Adnan Madanat called the film "The best Jordanian feature film." == Synopsis == Fish Above Sea Level is about Talal (Rabee Zureikat) a young Ammani professional, who discovers upon his father's death that he is penniless. His late father, in an attempt to shore up his failing investments, mortgaged the family house. Talal has few days to save the family house in [[Amman]] from foreclosure. His only way out is to sell a farm house once owned by his late father in a village by the [[Dead Sea]] with a dark past. At the village he meets Dawoud (Abdallah Dghemaat) a young farmer who lives in the farm house. Before Talal can do anything with the farm house, Dawoud's approval is essential. == Main Film Festivals == * African Diaspora Film Festival 2011 * Hollywood Black Film Festival 2011 == External links == * [http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117946816 Variety: Fish Above Sea Level by Ronnie Scheib] * {{IMDb title|1946227}} * [https://www.facebook.com/FishAboveSeaLevel?sk=info ''Fish Above Sea Level''] on Facebook * [http://alghad.com/index.php/article/482586.html ÿßŸÑÿ®Ÿäÿ∑ÿßÿ±: "ÿ≥ŸÖŸÉ ŸÅŸàŸÇ ÿ≥ÿ∑ÿ≠ ÿßŸÑÿ®ÿ≠ÿ±" ŸÖÿ®ŸÜŸä ÿπŸÑŸâ ÿÆŸÑŸÅŸäÿ© ÿ™ÿßÿ±ŸäÿÆŸäÿ© ŸÑŸÖŸÜÿ∑ŸÇÿ© ÿßŸÑÿ£ÿ∫Ÿàÿßÿ± ÿßŸÑÿ¨ŸÜŸàÿ®Ÿäÿ©] * [http://alghad.com/index.php/article/483086.html?section_id=0 ÿßŸÑÿ∫ÿØ :"ÿ≥ŸÖŸÉ ŸÅŸàŸÇ ÿ≥ÿ∑ÿ≠ ÿßŸÑÿ®ÿ≠ÿ±": ÿµŸàÿ± ŸÖÿØÿ±Ÿàÿ≥ÿ© Ÿàÿ≠Ÿàÿßÿ± Ÿäÿ≥ÿ™ŸÜÿØ ÿπŸÑŸâ ÿÆŸÑŸÅŸäÿ© ÿ™ÿßÿ±ŸäÿÆŸäÿ©] * [http://www.addustour.com/ViewTopic.aspx?ac=%5CSupplement2%5C2011%5C06%5CSupplement2_issue1336_day10_id332976.htm ÿßŸÑÿØÿ≥ÿ™Ÿàÿ±: ÿπŸÜ ŸÅŸäŸÑŸÖ ÿ≥ŸÖŸÉ ŸÅŸàŸÇ ÿ≥ÿ∑ÿ≠ ÿßŸÑÿ®ÿ≠ÿ± ] * [http://www.alkhaleej.ae/portal/e0777b29-5721-47e7-b005-f7f65f59c283.aspx ÿßŸÑÿÆŸÑŸäÿ¨: ŸÅŸäŸÑŸÖ ÿ£ÿ±ÿØŸÜŸä ŸàŸÖŸÑÿµŸÇ ] * [http://www.alrai.com/pages.php?news_id=396516 ÿßŸÑÿ±ÿ£Ÿä: ÿ≥ŸÖŸÉ ŸÅŸàŸÇ ÿ≥ÿ∑ÿ≠ ÿßŸÑÿ®ÿ≠ÿ± ŸÅŸäŸÑŸÖ ÿ±Ÿàÿßÿ¶Ÿä ÿ£ÿ±ÿØŸÜŸä ÿ∑ŸàŸäŸÑ ŸÑŸÑŸÖÿÆÿ±ÿ¨ ÿ≠ÿßÿ≤ŸÖ ÿßŸÑÿ®Ÿäÿ∑ÿßÿ±] * {{YouTube|C3Tu8mur_Os|ŸÅÿ∂ÿßÿ¶Ÿäÿ© ÿ±ÿ§Ÿäÿ©: ŸÖŸÇÿßÿ®ŸÑÿ© ŸÖÿπ ÿßŸÑŸÖÿÆÿ±ÿ¨ ÿ≠ÿßÿ≤ŸÖ ÿßŸÑÿ®Ÿäÿ∑ÿßÿ± Ÿàÿ£ÿ®ÿ∑ÿßŸÑ ÿßŸÑŸÅŸäŸÑŸÖ}} [[Category:2011 films]] [[Category:Jordanian films]] [[Category:2010s drama films]] [[Category:Arabic-language films]] [[Category:Nonlinear narrative films]] {{Jordan-film-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | name = Globally Responsible Leadership Initiative | image = | image_border = | size = 200px | alt = <!-- alt text; see [[WP:ALT]] --> | caption = | map = <!-- optional --> | msize = <!-- map size, optional, default 250px --> | malt = <!-- map alt text --> | mcaption = <!-- optional --> | map2 = | abbreviation = GRLI | motto = | predecessor = | successor = | formation = {{start date|2004}} | type = | status = | purpose = | headquarters = [[Brussels]], [[Belgium]] | location = | coords = | region_served = Global | membership = | language = <!-- official languages --> | general = <!-- Secretary General --> | leader_title = | leader_name = | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = <!-- position title for the leader of the org --> | leader_name3 = <!-- name of leader --> | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | key_people = | main_organ = <!-- gral. assembly, board of directors, etc --> | parent_organization = <!-- if one --> | affiliations = <!-- if any --> | budget = | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | website = {{URL|http://www.grli.org}} | remarks = | former name = }} The '''Globally Responsible Leadership Initiative''' ''(GRLI)'' is a [[non-profit]] community of [[business]]es as well as [[business school]]s and [[learning institution|educational institution]]s. Based in [[Belgium]], [[Brussels]], its purpose is to catalyse the development of globally responsible leadership and practice in organisations and society worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.grli.org/about/vision-mission/|title=Vision & Mission|publisher=GRLI|accessdate=2016-11-08}}</ref> The GRLI was founded in 2004 and counts numerous<!--769 according to LinkedIn, but not verifiable elsewhere so far--> organisations that are its partners and members.<ref name="linkedin">{{cite web|url=https://www.linkedin.com/company/globally-responsible-leadership-initiative-grli-|title=Globally Responsible Leadership Initiative (GRLI)|publisher=LinkedIn|accessdate=2016-11-08}}</ref>
Its strategic partners are the [[Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business]] (AACSB), the [[European Foundation for Management Development]] (EFMD) and the [[United Nations Global Compact]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.grli.org/network/strategic-partners/|title=Strategic Partners|publisher=GRLI|accessdate=2016-11-08}}</ref>
== Mission and Role == The mission of GRLI "to catalyze the development of globally responsible leadership and practice worldwide" is in line with the view promoted by GRLI that:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.grli.org/resources/grli-brief/|title=GRLI In Brief|publisher=GRLI|accessdate=2016-11-08}}</ref> :"The management challenge for the 21st Century is to create resilient societies, [[Sustainability|sustainable]] economies and a healthy environment in which all human beings can flourish and prosper. This calls for individual and collective [[leadership]] that strives not to be the best in the world but the best for the world."
The GRLI aims at building a world where leaders contribute to the creation of economic and societal progress in a globally responsible and sustainable way. A starting point for global leadership includes, according to GRLI, fairness, freedom, honesty, humanity, tolerance, transparency, responsibility and solidarity, and sustainability.<ref name="RascheKell2010-p177">{{cite book|author1=Andreas Rasche|author2=Georg Kell|title=The United Nations Global Compact: Achievements, Trends and Challenges|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5jxlPRKnh3AC&pg=PA177|date=16 June 2010|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-14553-4|pages=177}}</ref> Considered a resource for [[business education]] for cultivating leadership [[integrity]],<ref name="Chandler2014">{{cite book|author=Robert C. Chandler|title=Business and Corporate Integrity: Sustaining Organizational Compliance, Ethics, and Trust [2 volumes]: Sustaining Organizational Compliance, Ethics, and Trust|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yo2dAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA151|date=10 March 2014|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-0-313-39598-7|pages=151}}</ref> the GRLI challenges business schools and other learning institutions to explain and promote [[Organizational culture|organizational cultural]] changes toward [[social responsibility]]. It also cooperates with institutions of [[higher education]] to further develop their curricula.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://berkleycenter.georgetown.edu/programs/globally-responsible-leadership-initiative|title=Globally Responsible Leadership Initiative|publisher=Berkeley Center for Religion, Peace & World Affairs|accessdate=2016-11-08}}</ref>
The initiative has catalysed the creation of two new academic journals: the ''Journal of Global Responsibility'' and the ''Sustainability, Accounting, Management and Policy Journal''.<ref name="linkedin"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emeraldgrouppublishing.com/products/journals/affiliates.htm?id=jgr|title=Journal of Global Responsibility|publisher=[[Emerald Group Publishing]]|accessdate=2016-11-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emeraldgrouppublishing.com/products/journals/affiliates.htm?id=sampj|title=Sustainability Accounting, Management and Policy Journal|publisher=Emerald Group Publishing|accessdate=2016-11-08}}</ref>
The GRLI, in partnership with ''Principles for Responsible Management Education'' (PRME) and other networks, has given rise to several projects including:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.grli.org/2016/10/04/sp-agreement/|title=Leading global networks initiate Collaboratory for responsible management education|publisher=GRLI|accessdate=2016-11-08}}</ref> * the Sulitest ‚Äì an online sustainability literacy test developed and promoted by [[KEDGE Business School]] in France, * the AIM2Flourish global learning initiative ‚Äì a global initiative steering future business leaders towards achieving the UN [[Sustainable Development Goals]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aim2flourish.com/pages/about|title=Share Your AIM2Flourish Nominations Ideas|publisher=AIM2Flourish|accessdate=2016-11-08}}</ref> with an online platform for sharing positive stories on business as an agent for world benefit, championed by the [[Weatherhead School of Management]] at Case Western Reserve University in Ohio, USA; * the 50+20 Agenda ‚Äì a vision and global movement focused on "transforming management education in order to serve people, the planet and profit".
== History == The GRLI was founded in 2004 by the [[European Foundation for Management Development]] and the [[United Nations Global Compact]].<ref name="linkedin"/> The initiative's 2005 founding report identified a need for deep systemic change in business, recognizing that this change "needed to take place at the personal, organizational and systemic levels".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.grli.org/resources/globally-responsible-leadership-call-engagement/|title=Globally Responsible Leadership ‚Äì A call for engagement|publisher=GRLI|accessdate=2016-11-08}}</ref> It was founded with the purpose of developing a next generation of globally responsible leaders through the development and support of projects and initiatives.<ref>[http://www.grli.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/GRLI-Call-for-Action-English-2009-ISBN-978-1-871992-53-3.pdf The Globally Responsible Leader. A Call for Action], GRLI, 2009, {{ISBN|978-1-871992-53-3}}, page 2.</ref>
== See also == * [[Global citizenship]]
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
== External links == * [http://www.grli.org Official website]
[[Category:Business ethics organizations]] [[Category:Non-profit organisations based in Belgium]] [[Category:Global policy organizations]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2004]] [[Category:2004 establishments in Belgium]] [[Category:Social responsibility organizations]]

revision.text:
[[Image:HbbTV logo.jpg|thumb|right|The HbbTV logo]]
'''Hybrid Broadcast Broadband TV''' ('''HbbTV''') is both an industry standard ([[ETSI]] TS 102 796<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reghardware.com/2011/09/28/wtf_is_hbbtv/page2.html|title=WTF is... HbbTV?|work=reghardware.com|accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref>) and promotional initiative for hybrid digital TV to harmonise the [[broadcast]], [[IPTV]], and [[Internet access|broadband]] delivery of entertainment to the end consumer through connected TVs ([[smart TV]]s) and [[set-top box]]es.<ref>[http://www.hbbtv.org HbbTV website introduction] accessed August 28, 2009</ref> The HbbTV Association, comprising [[digital broadcasting]] and [[Internet]] industry companies, has established a standard for the delivery of broadcast TV and broadband TV to the home, through a single [[user interface]], creating an open platform as an alternative to proprietary technologies.<ref>{{cite press release|url=https://www.hbbtv.org/news-events/hbbtv-association-publishes-specification-for-operator-applications/ |title=HbbTV Association Publishes Specification for Operator Applications |publisher=HbbTV Association |date=December 19, 2017|accessdate=December 29, 2017}}</ref> Products and services using the HbbTV standard can operate over different broadcasting technologies, such as [[satellite television|satellite]], [[cable television|cable]], or [[terrestrial television|terrestrial]] networks.
HbbTV can show [[digital television]] content from a number of different sources including traditional [[Broadcast television systems|broadcast TV]], Internet, and connected devices in the home. To watch hybrid digital TV, consumers will need a hybrid IPTV [[set-top box]] with a range of input connectors, including [[Ethernet]] as well as at least one [[Antenna tuner|tuner]] for receiving broadcast TV signals. The tuner in a hybrid set-top box can be [[digital terrestrial television]] ([[DVB-T]], [[DVB-T2]]), [[digital cable]] ([[DVB-C]], [[DVB-C|DVB-C2]]) and digital satellite ([[DVB-S]], [[DVB-S2]]).
==History== The HbbTV Consortium (later HbbTV Association) was born in February 2009 from the French '''H4TV''' project and the '''German HTML profil''' project. HbbTV was first demonstrated in 2009, in France by [[France T√©l√©visions]] and two developers of Set Top Box technologies, Inverto Digital Labs of Luxembourg, and Pleyo of France, for the Roland Garros tennis sport event on a DTT transmission and an IP connection and in Germany using the [[Astra (satellites)|Astra]] satellite at [[Astra 19.2¬∞E|19.2¬∞ east]] during the [[Internationale Funkausstellung Berlin|IFA]] and [[International Broadcasting Convention|IBC]] exhibitions.<ref name="PR">{{cite press release|publisher=HbbTV Consortium |date=August 27, 2009 |url=http://www.hbbtv.org/news/HBBTV_PR_Final.pdf |title=New European initiative merges television with the power of the Internet |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091007125549/http://www.hbbtv.org/news/HBBTV_PR_Final.pdf |archivedate=October 7, 2009 }}</ref>
In May 2011, in an email sent on behalf of the HbbTV Consortium steering group, supporters of the consortium were invited to become full members. The transitional arrangements towards the opening of membership would involve withdrawal of a number of privileges, including participation in meetings and contribution to further versions of the specification, from supporters that did not sign up. The cost of membership was around ‚Ç¨7,000 for the first year.<ref>Julian Clover. [http://www.broadbandtvnews.com/2011/05/16/hbbtv-consortium-open-for-membership/ ''HbbTV consortium open for membership''], Broadband TV News, May 16, 2011. Retrieved June 25, 2011</ref>
In June 2014, the HbbTV Association merged with the [[Open IPTV Forum]], a similar industry organisation for end-to-end Internet Protocol television ([[IPTV]]) services formed in 2007, which worked closely with the HbbTV initiative on browser and media specifications for network-connected televisions and set-top boxes. The two initiatives were combined under the HbbTV Association‚Äôs banner because the markets for IPTV, [[Over-the-top content|OTT]] and hybrid broadcast and broadband TV are converging.<ref>[http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/open-iptv-forum-and-hbbtv-association-merge-their-activities-263418211.html ''Open IPTV Forum and HbbTV Association Merge their Activities''], PR Newswire, June 17, 2014. Retrieved February 26, 2015</ref>
In September 2016 it was announced that the Smart TV Alliance, founded in 2012 by [[LG Electronics]], [[Panasonic]], [[Toshiba]] and [[TP Vision]], was to merge with HbbTV, extending the scope of the HbbTV specification to address [[Over-the-top content|over-the-top]] services and to streamline standards. The merger is expected to be finalised within a year.<ref>[http://www.broadbandtvnews.com/2016/09/01/hbbtv-association-joins-forces-with-smart-tv-alliance/ ''HbbTV Association joins forces with Smart TV Alliance''] Broadband TV News, September 1, 2016. Retrieved October 31, 2016</ref>
==Applications and consumer products== Services delivered through HbbTV include enhanced [[teletext]], [[Catch-up tv|catch-up services]], [[video-on-demand]], [[EPG]], interactive advertising, personalisation, voting, games, [[social networking]], and other multimedia applications.
At the May 2010 Broadcast and Beyond Conference in London, Thomas Wrede, VP Product Management Media at SES, said that he expected HbbTV devices to be launched commercially from June 2010 with a consumer market introduction at the IFA consumer electronics trade fair in Berlin in September 2010. Wrede also noted that Humax and Videoweb both had conformant products and that at the recent ANGA Cable trade fair in Cologne, 12 manufacturers exhibited HbbTV devices, with another six working on product introduction.<ref>Colin Mann. [http://www.advanced-television.com/2010/may17_may21.htm#f2 ''HbbTV set for commercial launch''], Advanced-television.com, May 21, 2010. Retrieved May 21, 2010</ref>
==Benefits== HbbTV devices enables consumers to view all of these advanced services on their TV, via a single device. In addition to a broader range of content from TV providers ‚Äì ranging from traditional broadcast TV, video on-demand and catch-up TV services, like [[BBC iPlayer]] ‚Äì hybrid digital TV also provides consumers with access to [[user-generated content]] either stored on an external [[hard drive]], or [[cloud storage]], and to a range of advanced interactive services and [[Internet]] applications.
Hybrid set-top boxes are increasingly commonplace amongst [[pay-TV]] operators, as they look to meet the changing media consumption trends for more video content, advanced interactivity and internet applications, like [[social networking]]. Operators like [[n]], a division of ITI Neovision in [[Poland]], and [[Telekom Austria]] are two of the leaders in the deployment of hybrid set-top boxes. The 2010 IPTV World Forum Awards recognized a hybrid solution as the best interactive TV service/application: the solution, developed by [[Advanced Digital Broadcast]], is the first [[three-way hybrid]] platform that enables content delivered via [[Satellite]], [[Terrestrial television|Terrestrial]] and [[Ethernet]] networks to be viewed on a television.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvover.net/2010/03/26/IPTV+World+Series+Awards+2010+Winners+Announced.aspx|title=IPTV World Series Awards 2010 Winners Announced - TVover.net|publisher=}}</ref>
== Association membership ==
The HbbTV consortium has over 50 supporting members from the [[Consumer electronics|CE]] and Broadcast industries, including:<ref>[https://www.hbbtv.org/membership/ HbbTV Association membership list]. Accessed December 28, 2017</ref>
* Standardisation and research bodies: [[Digital TV Group]], [[Digital UK]], [[Dolby]], [[European Broadcasting Union|EBU]], [[Fraunhofer Institute for Open Communication Systems|Fraunhofer FOKUS]], [[Institut f√ºr Rundfunktechnik|IRT]], [[Netherlands Organisation for Applied Scientific Research|TNO]], [[RT-RK]],
* Broadcasting: [[Arqiva]], [[BBC]], [[BT Group|BT]], Cellnex, [[Deutsche Telekom]], [[Hellenic Broadcasting Corporation|ERT]], [[Eutelsat]], [[Freesat]], [[Freeview (Australia)]], [[Freeview (New Zealand)]], [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]], Media Broadcast, [[ProSiebenSat.1 Media|ProSiebenSat.1]], Red Bull Media House, [[Mediaset|Reti Televisive Italiane]], [[RTL Group]], [[SES S.A.|SES]], [[Sky UK]], [[Swiss Broadcasting Corporation|SRG SSR]], [[TDF Group|TDF]], [[TV3 (Catalonia)|TV3]], [[Tiv√π Sat]]
* Software and Content protection: [[Access (company)|Access]], [[Advanced Digital Broadcast|ADB]], [[BearingPoint]], Espial, [[Intertrust Technologies Corporation|Intertrust]], Irdeto, iWedia, Kudelski, Seraphic, Sophia Digital, Suresoft, TARA Systems, [[Cinavia|Verance]], Vewd, [[Viaccess]], Wipro, Zenterio
* CE devices and components manufacturers: [[Ar√ßelik]], [[Changhong]], CVTE, [[Hisense]], [[Humax]], Jiuzhou, [[LG Corporation|LG]], [[Loewe AG|LOEWE]], MediaTek, MStar, Novatek, [[Panasonic]], [[Sagemcom]], [[Samsung]], Sharp, Smit, [[Skyworth]], [[Sony]], [[TCL Corporation|TCL]], [[TP Vision]], [[Vestel]], Voxtok
* Test Houses for CE devices: Eurofins Digital, Labwise
The HbbTV Association steering group currently comprises representatives from: Cellnex Telecom, [[Deutsche Telekom]], [[Digital TV Group]], [[European Broadcasting Union|EBU]], Eurofins Digital, [[Freesat]], IRT, [[LG Corporation|LG]], [[Opera Software]], [[Mediaset|Reti Televisive Italiane]], [[RTL Group]], [[Samsung]], [[Sony]], [[Tiv√π Sat]], [[Netherlands Organisation for Applied Scientific Research|TNO]], and [[TP Vision]].<ref>[https://www.hbbtv.org/working-groups/#steering-group HbbTV Association Steering Group]. Accessed December 29, 2017</ref>
== Standard ==
As well as helping consumers/viewers, the introduction of the HbbTV standard is of benefit to both equipment manufacturers and content providers who at the moment have to produce hardware or content specific to each country to meet the de facto standard in that country. The establishment of a unified European HbbTV standard means "content owners and application developers can write once and deploy to many countries".<ref>Richard Baker. [http://www.antplc.blogspot.com ''European initiative merges television with the power of the internet'']. ANT Software video blog August 27, 2009. Retrieved September 1, 2009</ref>
The HbbTV specification was developed by industry members of the consortium and is based on elements of existing standards and web technologies including the [[Open IPTV Forum]],<ref name="advanced">{{Cite web|url=http://advanced-television.com/2012/12/05/oipf-commissions-digital-tv-labs-test-suite/|accessdate=14 January 2013|title=OIPF commissions Digital TV Labs test suite|publisher=Advanced-Television.com|date=5 December 2012}}</ref> [[Consumer Electronics Association|CEA]], [[Digital Video Broadcasting|DVB]], and [[W3C]].<ref name="PR"/>
The [[European Broadcasting Union]] General Assembly has given its support to the HbbTV initiative and described the technology as "one of the most exciting developments in the media today".<ref>[http://www.broadbandtvnews.com/2009/12/07/ebu-general-assembly-backs-hbb/''EBU General Assembly backs HBB'']. ''Broadband TV News'' December 7, 2009. Retrieved January 11, 2010</ref>
The standard specification has been submitted by the end of November 2009 to [[ETSI]], who published it under reference ETSI TS 102 796 in June 2010.<ref>[http://www.etsi.org/deliver/etsi_ts/102700_102799/102796/01.01.01_60/ts_102796v010101p.pdf TS 102 796 : "Hybrid Broadcast Broadband TV"], on the [[ETSI]] website</ref> There is an accompanying Test Suite that provides a set of test material to test HbbTV device implementations, suitable for manufacturers of devices, including software and hardware components that implement the HbbTV specification (ETSI TS 102 796 v1.1.1).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hbbtv.org/pages/about_hbbtv/hbbtv_test_suite.php|title=HbbTV Test Suite|publisher=}}</ref> In November 2012 [http://www.eurofins-digitaltesting.com/test-solutions/consumer-device-testing/hbbtv/ Eurofins Digital Testing (then Digital TV Labs)] became the first Registered Test Centre.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurofins-digitaltesting.com/test-solutions/consumer-device-testing/hbbtv/|title=Digital TV Labs - Digital TV Labs Is The First Official HbbTV Test Centre|publisher=}}</ref>
The applications for HbbTV are HTML-based, making use of [[HTML5]] and the [[CE-HTML]] user interface language,<ref>Robert Briel. [http://www.broadbandtvnews.com/2009/08/27/german-rtl-to-support-hbbtv/ ''German RTL to support HbbTV'']</ref> but utilise only a sub-set of standard web standards, developers have to use specialist validation tools.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitaltv-labs.com/products/consumer_electronics/details/hbbtv_for_app_developers|title=Digital TV Labs - HbbTV for Application Developers|publisher=}}</ref>
In September 2017 the HbbTV Association announced the publication of its IPTV specification by ETSI as TS 103 555. This specification builds on HbbTV 2.0 and defines how audio-visual content delivered by an IPTV service can be presented on HbbTV terminals (such as set-top boxes and televisions) - both hybrid terminals with an IP connection and an RF-based broadcast connection, and pure IPTV terminals with only an IP connection.<ref>{{cite press release|publisher=HbbTV Association|date=September 26, 2017 |url=https://www.hbbtv.org/news-events/hbbtv-association-announces-publication-of-iptv-specification|title=HbbTV Association Announces Publication of IPTV Specification|accessdate=October 27, 2017}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccf;" ! HbbTV edition ! ETSI edition<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hbbtv.org/resource-library/#specifications|title=HbbTV specifications|publisher=HbbTV.org}}</ref> |- | HbbTV 1.0 | TS 102 796 v1.1.1 ‚Äì June 2006 |- | HbbTV 1.5 | TS 102 796 v1.2.1 ‚Äì Nov. 2012 |- | HbbTV 2.0 | TS 102 796 v1.3.1 ‚Äì Nov. 2015 |- |- |} The next incremental version of the HbbTV standard is expected to include functionality from the [[MHEG-5]] interactive middleware platform used for digital terrestrial TV in the UK, to facilitate the transition from MHEG-5 to HbbTV as the mandated system in the UK.
== Roll out == Several countries worldwide, and in Europe in particular, have adopted the HbbTV standard and/or operated HbbTV services and trials. As of December 2011, HbbTV services were in regular operation in France, Germany and Spain, with announcements of adoption in Austria, Czech Republic, Slovakia, Denmark, Netherlands, Poland, Switzerland, Turkey, and trials in Australia, China, Japan, and the United States.<ref>Dr. Klaus Illgner-Fehns, Chairman HbbTV consortium. [http://www.hbbtv.org/pages/news_events/Sym-12-2011/1.1%20-%20HbbTV%20Consortium%20%20-%20HD-Forum%20Symposium%20111205.pdf '' Introduction to HbbTV'']. Presentation December 5/6, 2011. Retrieved March 27, 2012</ref>
As of October 2015, 27 countries have launched HbbTV services with the most recent being the UK, New Zealand, Senegal, Namibia, Bosnia and Estonia.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hbbtv.org/news-events/hbbtv-association-and-the-dtg-announce-hbbtv-symposium-2015/|title=HbbTV and DTG announce 4th annual symposium|work=HbbTV|accessdate=24 November 2015}}</ref> In October 2014, the HbbTV Association announced that over 20 countries had launched HbbTV services with Italy and Saudi being the most recent to launch.<ref name="broadbandtvnews.com">Breil, Robert [http://www.broadbandtvnews.com/2014/10/28/hbbtv-momentum-continues-to-grow/ ''HbbTV momentum continues to grow''] Broadband TV Nerws October 28, 2014 Retrieved March 27, 2015</ref>
=== Europe === In 2010 German broadcaster [[RTL Television]] introduced a new information service, HD Text, making use of HbbTV and the [[CE-HTML]] user interface language,<ref>Robert Briel. [http://www.broadbandtvnews.com/2009/08/27/german-rtl-to-support-hbbtv/ ''German RTL to support HbbTV'']. ''Broadband TV News'' August 27, 2009. Retrieved August 30, 2009</ref> and in 2012 launched an online music video service (Clipfish Music) on its HbbTV portal allowing access to TV viewers.<ref>Robert Briel. [http://www.broadbandtvnews.com/2012/03/12/rtl-showing-music-clips-via-hbbtv/ ''RTL showing music clips via HbbTV'']. ''Broadband TV News'' March 12, 2012. Retrieved March 27, 2012</ref>
In 2011 the Dutch national public networks, [[Nederland 1]], [[Nederland 2|2]], and [[Nederland 3|3]] began broadcasting HbbTV "[[Red Button (digital television)|red button]]" applications including an [[electronic program guide|program guide]] and [[catch-up TV]] instead of developing separate apps for particular platforms.<ref>Robert Briel. [http://www.broadbandtvnews.com/2011/04/28/dutch-pubcasters-commit-to-hbbtv/ ''Dutch pubcasters commit to HbbTV'']. ''Broadband TV News'' April 28, 2011. Retrieved June 25, 2011</ref>
In France, the government-owned public broadcaster, [[France T√©l√©visions]] selected HbbTV for its interactive news, sports and weather service, and plans to add catch-up TV and social media sharing capability.<ref>[http://onlinereporter.com/2011/09/13/french-public-broadcaster-goes-for-hbbtv/'' French Public Broadcaster Goes For HbbTV'']. ''Online Reporter'' September 13, 2011. Retrieved March 27, 2012</ref> International French news channel [[France 24]] has announced that it will launch an HbbTV interactive news service in 2012 via the [[Astra 19.2¬∞E]] satellites, with support from Orange and [[SES S.A.|SES]].<ref>{{cite press release |publisher=France 24 |date=December 21, 2011 |url=http://www.france24.com/en/globecast-france24-orange-ses-hbbTV|title=Globecast and FRANCE 24 to lead HbbTV experiment with Orange and SES}}</ref>
In November 2011 Spain‚Äôs Ministry of Industry approved a document signed by 54 companies adopting the HbbTV standard and broadcasters, [[Mediaset Espa√±a Comunicaci√≥n|Mediaset Espa√±a]], [[Canal+ (Spanish satellite broadcasting company)|Canal+]] and [[Telef√≥nica]] have run pilot services.<ref>David Del Valle. [http://advanced-television.com/index.php/2011/11/25/spain-selects-hbbtv-standard/ Spain selects HbbTV standard'']. ''Advanced Television'' November 25, 2011. Retrieved March 27, 2012</ref>
The first tests of HbbTV services in Poland were started by TVN in March 2012.<ref>Chris Dziadul. [http://www.broadbandtvnews.com/2012/03/13/hbbtv-starts-in-poland/''HbbTV starts in Poland'']. ''Broadband TV News'' March 13, 2012. Retrieved March 27, 2012</ref>
In the UK, the Freeview Play platform has been launched implementing an HbbTV 2.0 catch-up service on DVB-T/T2. [[Freesat]], the [[free-to-air]] satellite TV service broadcast via [[Astra 28.2¬∞E]], has revealed that the second generation "G2" specification for Freesat receivers will use HbbTV, to take advantage of the digital TV chipsets being developed for that standard (but retaining [[MHEG-5]] compatibility of the first generation Freesat receivers).<ref>"Freesat lets slip next-gen G2 spec" ''What Satellite & Digital TV'' May 2011 p11</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.broadbandtvnews.com/2011/03/09/new-freesat-boxes-to-run-on-hbbtv/|title=New Freesat boxes to run on HbbTV|publisher=Broadband TV News|first=Julian|last=Clover|date=March 9, 2011|accessdate=March 28, 2012}}</ref> While the [[Digital TV Group]] approved [[D-book]] 7, a detailed interoperability specification between digital terrestrial television and HbbTV-based products and services.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.dtg.org.uk/dtg/press_release.php?id=31 |title=UK HbbTV based 'Connected TV' specification formally approved for publication |publisher=Digital TV Group |date=March 3, 2011 |accessdate=March 28, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120504051700/http://dtg.org.uk/dtg/press_release.php?id=31 |archivedate=May 4, 2012 |df= }}</ref>
In Nordic region (Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, Sweden, and Ireland) the NorDig standardization forum has adopted the HbbTV specification which replaces DVB-MHP as the common API for hybrid digital receivers.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.hbbtv.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/PRESS-RELEASE_NorDig-HbbTV.pdf|title=NorDig releases a HbbTV Addendum (succeeding DVB MHP as NorDig‚Äôs API) |date=April 4, 2012 |accessdate=May 5, 2012 }}</ref>
In Finland the national HDTV Forum has adopted the NorDig Unified Specification for Hybrid Services. The members of HDTV Forum see the HbbTV specification having a wide market acceptance supporting wide range of TV applications and new hybrid services.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://sofiadigital.com/finland-is-setting-the-standard-for-connected-tv-services/|title=Finland is setting the standard for connected TV services|date=April 17, 2012|accessdate=August 26, 2014}}</ref> HbbTV services have been on air in Finland since March 2013 in the nationwide terrestrial TV network. Current services include 'red button' services and an enhanced programme guide application.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.digitaltveurope.net/38582/digita-launches-hbbtv-with-sofia-digital/|title=Digita launches HbbTV with Sofia Digital|date=March 14, 2014|accessdate=August 26, 2014}}</ref> Several broadcasters in Finland use the HbbTV platform. Those are [[Yle]] <ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.digita.fi/in_english/media/yle_areena_joins_smart_tv_hybrid_services_provided_via_digitas_tv_network.4241.news|title=Yle Areena joins smart TV hybrid services provided via Digita's TV network|date=Oct 30, 2015|accessdate=Jan 25, 2017}}</ref> [[Nelonen Media]] <ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.digitaltveurope.net/412051/hbbtv-1-5-version-of-ott-tv-service-ruutu-tv-now-on-digita/|title=HbbTV 1.5 version of OTT TV service Ruutu TV now on Digita|date=Aug 14, 2015|accessdate=Jan 25, 2017}}</ref> and MTV. <ref>{{url=http://www.digita.fi/kuluttajille/tv/hybridi-tv/hybridi-tv-vastaanottimet/|accessdate=Jan 25, 2017}}</ref>
In Switzerland the first HbbTV service, which is called ''RTS+'', was launched on March 5, 2013, on [[SRG SSR]] French speaking channels [[RTS Un|RTSun HD]] and [[RTS Deux|RTSdeux HD]]. The service was developed by ''SwissTXT''.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.srgssr.ch/en/television/1052/|title=RTS+, the new, interactive TV service|date=March 5, 2013|accessdate=March 25, 2013}}</ref>
Italy had launched HbbTV services by October 2014.<ref name="broadbandtvnews.com"/>
In Estonia HbbTV was adopted in March 10, 2015.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://tasutatv.ee/pressiteade-eesti-suuremad-telekanalid-kaivitasid-koos-leviraga-hubriidtv/|title=Estonian largest TV channels and Levira initiated Hybrid TV (in Estonian)|date=March 10, 2015|accessdate=March 11, 2015}}</ref>
In Greece HbbTV was adopted in November, 2016 by [[Cosmote TV]].
[[Turkish Radio and Television Corporation]] launched its HbbTV app, TRT Plus ({{lang-tr|TRT Artƒ±}}), in 2014.
In Turkey, FOX TV and Kanal7 launched its HbbTV EPG app (Fox'da ne var?, Kanal7 yayƒ±n akisi) in 2016 and 2017 provided by Turkish HBBTV company Admongrel. Service was deployed with help of Castoola HbbTV platform.
In 2017 first interactive preroll advertisement campaign (Bosch advertisement) was launched by Admongrel, Adform and Kanal7.
In December 2017, the BBC launched a UK nationwide HbbTV broadcast service. The service provides users the opportunity to launch connected TV applications from broadcast as well as offering broadcast TV applications for radio stations.<ref>{{cite press release|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/rd/blog/2017-12-bbc-hbbtv-interactive-tv|title=The BBC Launches the First HbbTV Service in the UK|date=December 20, 2017}}</ref>
=== Australia and New Zealand === Freeview New Zealand launched its HbbTV platform in New Zealand in July 2015, under the registered trade mark name "FreeviewPlus", with their DVB-T service (Freeview|HD); followed by an extension to the DVB-S service (Freeview Satellite) in April 2016.<ref>{{cite web|last=|first=|title=Smarter Way To Watch TV with FreeviewPlus|url=http://www.freeviewnz.tv/news/smarter-way-to-watch-tv-with-freeviewplus.aspx|work=Freeview|accessdate=24 March 2014}}</ref>
=== Western Asia and Middle East ===
Saudi Arabia had launched HbbTV services by October 2014.<ref name="broadbandtvnews.com"/> In early 2015, several broadcasters in Turkey have reportedly begun using the HbbTV platform and services provided by Admongrel <ref>http://www.broadbandtvnews.com/2017/01/13/hbbtv-breakthrough-in-turkey/</ref>
=== Other Locations ===
HbbTV is being reviewed and tested, with interest from US, Argentina, Japan, China (which is conducting a trial), Malaysian Broadcasters (where DVB-T2 broadcasting will soon start) and Singapore (where Mediacorp is introducing its service through Toggle).
== HbbTV set-top boxes == Since the beginning of 2010 a new generation of advanced HbbTV [[IPTV]] set-top box has emerged in the UK with the advent of [[DVB-T2]] services.<ref>http://www.freeview.co.uk/blog/?p=293</ref> [[DVB-T2]] [[Antenna tuner|tuner]]s enable the reception of [[free-to-air]] terrestrial [[high-definition video|high-definition]] programmes to be received in around twelve areas of the UK.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/digitaltv/news/a182608/bbc-arqiva-outline-dtt-hd-upgrade-plans.html|title=BBC, Arqiva outline DTT HD upgrade plans|work=Digital Spy}}</ref>
High definition digital terrestrial services have encouraged a range of device manufacturers to launch new hybrid set-top boxes for the UK consumer retail market. Some of these companies have launched devices that, in addition to allowing traditional broadcast and IP-delivered services to be received, have an integrated [[smart-card]] slot that allows consumers to receive encrypted [[Premium television]] services including sports and movies.<ref>http://www.techradar.com/news/home-cinema/high-definition/freeview-hd-the-definitive-list-of-boxes-680661</ref>
Such boxes enable the aggregation of traditional linear TV broadcasts with video delivered via both managed (cable) and unmanaged [[IP network]]s (the internet). This allows viewers to view broadcast television and internet video on their flat screen TVs, alongside advanced interactive services, such as [[video on demand]], [[internet]] browsing, and [[time shifting|time-shifted TV]].
A hybrid IPTV platform helps operators increase [[average revenue per user]] (ARPU), whilst eliminating expensive duplication in network infrastructure investment. IPTV [[customer-premises equipment]] (CPE) allows pay TV operators to deploy home entertainment, with video telephony, surveillance, gaming, shopping, e-government, and interactive services amongst the service mix that can be offered.
== Tools == '''OpenHbb''' is a collaborative project funded by the French government (DGCIS), the [[Pays de la Loire]] and [[√éle-de-France]] regions, and the Conseil G√©n√©ral des Hauts-de-Seine (council for the [[d√©partement|department]] of [[Hauts-de-Seine]]) as part of the Images & R√©seaux and Cap Digital competitiveness clusters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.appmarket.tv/news/591-openhbb-.html|title=OpenHbb project to present a leading platform for interactive TV [591] - Archives - TV App Market|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=fr&u=http://openhbb.eu/&prev=/search%3Fq%3Dopenhbb%26hl%3Den%26client%3Dfirefox-a%26hs%3DHD3%26tbo%3Dd%26rls%3Dorg.mozilla:en-US:official&sa=X&ei=2kC3UOWMNuWc0QW1lYGgBw&ved=0CDUQ7gEwAA|title=Google Translate|publisher=}}</ref>
Opera has developed an '''HbbTV Emulator''', available for free on their website.[http://business.opera.com/products/tv-emulator] This emulator is currently in beta version.
'''[http://validator.digitaltv-labs.com/ HbbTV App Validator]''' is a free, cloud-based tool for HbbTV app conformance validation provided by [http://www.eurofins-digitaltesting.com/ Eurofins Digital Testing] (formerly Digital TV Labs). App Validator uses static analysis to check for simple problems and use of non-standard language features in your HbbTV app's [[XHTML]], [[JavaScript]] and [[CSS]].
There is also a Firefox add-on, '''[http://firehbbtv.iptv.aw.atos.net/ FireHbbTV]''', as a free HbbTV emulator.
'''OpenCaster''' is a free GPL licensed software for transport stream broadcasting supporting HbbTV data [http://www.avalpa.com/the-key-values/15-free-software/33-opencaster].
== Security and privacy concerns == [https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/about-90-percent-of-smart-tvs-vulnerable-to-remote-hacking-via-rogue-tv-signals/ About 90% of Smart TVs Vulnerable to Remote Hacking via Rogue TV Signals] Rafael Scheel of Oneconsult AG developed a Radio Frequency based remote exploit using HbbTV that provides root access. He provides counter measures in his Feb 22, 2017 presentation to the European Broadcasting Union Media Cybersecurity Seminar.
Academic research by Columbia University has revealed possible security flaws in HbbTV.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-27761756|title=BBC News - Smart TVs subverted by radio attack|work=BBC News}}</ref><ref>http://iss.oy.ne.ro/Aether.pdf</ref> According to the blog of Martin Herfurt (referenced in the Columbia paper), the HbbTV standard allows an attacker to inject [[malware]] into an HbbTV-enabled smart television that can cause it to do various things like modifying the content being displayed, mining [[Bitcoin]]s, or attacking other devices connected to the network that the television is connected to.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mherfurt.wordpress.com/2013/06/01/security-concerns-with-hbbtv/|title=Security concerns with HbbTV|work=Martin Herfurt's Blog}}</ref>
The HbbTV Association has responded to the reports with a statement "HbbTV welcomes and appreciates the academic research on security threats in set-top boxes and TVs based on our specifications. The HbbTV Association continuously reviews such situations and has determined that there is limited potential for a security breach based on this research. Nevertheless, as ever, our upcoming HbbTV specification will include further appropriate security solutions."<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.hbbtv.org/pages/news_events/pdf/Communication%20Statement%20Options%20final.pdf |title=HbbTV Statement Regarding Possible Security Concerns |publisher=HbbTV Association |date=June 26, 2014 |accessdate=June 26, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140929182653/http://www.hbbtv.org/pages/news_events/pdf/Communication%20Statement%20Options%20final.pdf |archivedate=September 29, 2014 |df= }}</ref>
In 2013 researchers from [[TU Darmstadt]] found widespread non-consensual use of [[web analytics]] technologies, such as [[third-party cookie]]s, in HbbTV content to track viewing patterns.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bsi.bund.de/SharedDocs/Downloads/DE/BSI/Veranstaltungen/ITSiKongress/2013/Marco_Ghiglieri_15052013.pdf |title=BSI: Marco Ghiglieri: HbbTV ‚Äì I Know What You Are Watching! |date=28 May 2013 |publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141219090724/https://www.bsi.bund.de/SharedDocs/Downloads/DE/BSI/Veranstaltungen/ITSiKongress/2013/Marco_Ghiglieri_15052013.pdf |archivedate=19 December 2014 |df= }}</ref><ref>https://www.sit.tu-darmstadt.de/fileadmin/user_upload/Group_SIT/Publications/05_Ghiglieri_Oswald_Tews_HbbTV-I_Know_What_Your_Are_Watching.pdf</ref>

{{Infobox spaceflight | name = Intelsat VA F-11 ‚Üí Intelsat 511 | image = | image_caption = | mission_type = [[Communications satellite|Communication]] | operator = [[Intelsat]] | website = | COSPAR_ID = 1985-055A{{cite web|url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1985-055A|title=INTELSAT 5A F-11|publisher=National Space Science Data Center|accessdate=April 23, 2017}} | SATCAT = 15873 | mission_duration = 15 years | spacecraft_bus = [[SSL 1300|Intelsat-V]] bus | manufacturer = [[Ford Aerospace]] | BOL_mass = {{convert|1098|kg|lb}}{{cite web|url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/intelsat-5a.htm|title=Intelsat-5a|publisher=Gunter's Space Page|accessdate=April 23, 2017}} | launch_mass = {{convert|2013|kg|lb}} | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|May 19, 1983, 00:44|timezone=yes}} UTC{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/launchlog.txt|title=Launch Log|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|work=Jonathan's Space Page|accessdate=April 23, 2017}} | launch_rocket = [[Atlas-Centaur|Atlas-Centaur G-D1AR]] | launch_site = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Launch Complex 36|LC-36B]] | launch_contractor = [[NASA]] | entered_service = | disposal_type = Decommissioned | deactivated = {{end-date|August, 2003}} | orbit_epoch = April 23, 2017{{cite web|url=https://www.n2yo.com/satellite/?s=15873|title=Intelsat 511|work=N2yo.com|accessdate=April 23, 2017}} | orbit_reference = [[Geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Geostationary orbit|Geostationary]] | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|35,789.3|km|mi|sp=us}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|36,905.3|km|mi|sp=us}} | orbit_inclination = 15.2 degrees | orbit_semimajor = {{convert|42218|km|mi|sp=us}} | orbit_period = 1,438.8 minutes | orbit_longitude = 29.5¬∞ W (original position)
96.3¬∞ W (current position) | apsis = gee | trans_band = 26 [[C band (IEEE)|C-band]]
6 {{Ku band}} | trans_frequency = | trans_capacity = | trans_coverage = | trans_TWTA = | trans_EIRP = | trans_HPBW = | programme = ''Intelsat V'' | previous_mission = [[Intelsat VA F-10]] | next_mission = [[Intelsat VA F-12]] }} '''Intelsat 511''', previously named '''Intelsat VA F-11''', was a [[communications satellite]] operated by [[Intelsat]]. Launched in 1985, it was the eleventh of fifteen [[Intelsat V]] satellites to be launched. The Intelsat V series was constructed by [[Ford Aerospace]], based on the [[SSL 1300|Intelsat-V]] [[satellite bus]]. Intelsat VA F-11 was part of an advanced series of satellites designed to provide greater telecommunications capacity for [[Intelsat]]'s global network. The satellite was deactivated on August, 2003. The satellite was successfully launched into space on June 30, 1985, at 00:44 UTC, by means of an [[Atlas-Centaur|Atlas SLV-3D Centaur-D1AR]] vehicle from the [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]], [[Florida]], [[United States]]. It had a launch mass of 2,013 kg.{{cite web|url=http://www.tbs-satellite.com/tse/online/sat_intelsat_511.html|title=INTELSAT 511|publisher=TSE|accessdate=April 23, 2017}} The Intelsat VA F-11 was equipped with 6 [[Ku-band]] transponders more 26 [[C band (IEEE)|C-band]] [[transponder]]s for 15,000 audio circuits and 2 TV channels. ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Portal|Spaceflight}} {{Intelsat}} {{Orbital launches in 1983}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1983]] [[Category:Intelsat satellites]] {{spacecraft-stub}} {{US-spacecraft-stub}}

{{update|date=August 2018}} The '''Junior Monaco Kart Cup''' is a [[kart racing]] event ruled by the [[Commission Internationale de Karting|CIK]]-[[F√©d√©ration Internationale de l'Automobile|FIA]] and organized by the Automobile Club de Monaco, it takes place each year in [[Monaco]]. [[File:Monte Carlo Formula 1 track map with streets.svg|thumb|right|The track with the local streets shown. This variant uses corners 12 to 17]]The event see young drivers compete with [[KF3]] karts, a class for top drivers aged 12 to 15. The course circuit follows the lower part of the famous [[Circuit de Monaco|Formula One track]], in a large section of the port, from ''Tabac corner'', round the swimming pool, and on to the ''Rascasse'' before entering the F1 track's pit lane. A ramp and a hairpin connect this part of the track back to the port section. ==Winners== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%;" ! Year ! Driver ! Chassis / Engine / Tires ! revision.text:
'''Nigeria Security and Civil Defence corps''' (NSCDC) is a [[para-military institution]] that was established in May 1967 by the [[Nigeria|Federal Republic of Nigeria]], with the act of [[National Assembly (Nigeria)]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/minister-writes-vp-nsa-over-igp-s-call-to-scrap-nscdc/75526/|title=Minister Writes VP, NSA over IGP‚Äôs Call to Scrap NSCDC, Articles - THISDAY LIVE|publisher=|accessdate=20 September 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150713232100/http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/minister-writes-vp-nsa-over-igp-s-call-to-scrap-nscdc/75526/|archivedate=13 July 2015|df=}}</ref> The act was amended in 2007, to enhance the statutory duties of the corp.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2010/02/why-we-deserve-to-be-armed-nscdc/|title=Why we deserve to be armed-NSCDC|work=Vanguard News|accessdate=20 September 2014}}</ref> Nigerian Security and Civil Defence Corps is a para-military agency of the Government of the Federal Republic of Nigeria that is commissioned to provide measures against threat and any form of attack or disaster against the nation and its citizenry. The corps is statutorily empowered by lay Act No. 2 of 2003 and amended by Act 6 of 4th June 2007.
The Corps is empowered to institute legal proceedings by or in then and of the Attorney General of the Federation in accordance with the provisions of the constitution of the Federal Republic of Nigeria against any person or persons suspected to have committed an offence, maintain an armed squad in order to bear fire arms among others to strengthen the corps in the discharge of its statutory duties
The Nigeria Security and Civil Defence Corps was first introduced in May 1967 during the Nigerian Civil War within the then Federal Capital Territory of Lagos for the purpose of sensitization and protection of the civil populace. It was then known as Lagos Civil Defence Committee.
It later metamorphosed into the present day Nigeria Security and Civil Defence Corps in 1970. On inception, the Corps had the objective of carrying out some educational and enlightenment campaigns in and around the Federal Capital of Lagos to sensitize members of the civil populace on enemy attacks and how to save themselves from danger as most Nigerians living in and around Lagos territory then had little or no knowledge about war and its implications. Members of the Committee deemed it important to educate through electronic and print media on how to guide themselves during air raids, bomb attacks, identify bombs and how to dive into trenches during bomb blast.
In 1984, the Corps was transformed into a National security outfit and in 1988, there was a major re-structuring of the Corps that led to the establishment of Commands throughout the Federation, including Abuja, and the addition of special functions by the Federal Government. On 28th June 2003, an Act to give statutory backing to the NSCDC passed by the National Assembly was signed into law by Chief Olusegun Obasanjo, GCFR, the former president and Commander in chief of the Armed Forces, Federal Republic of Nigeria.
==Statutory duties== The primary function of the NSCDC is to protect lives and properties in conjunction with [[Nigeria Police Force|Nigeria police]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2013/06/civil-defence-wants-synergy-on-counter-terrorism/|title=Civil Defence wants synergy on counter-terrorism|work=Vanguard News|accessdate=20 September 2014}}</ref> One of the crucial function of the corp is to protect pipelines from vandalism.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newtelegraphonline.com/police-nscdc-battle-over-oil-pipelines/|title=New Telegraph ‚Äì Police, NSCDC battle over oil pipelines|publisher=|accessdate=20 September 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140924041038/http://newtelegraphonline.com/police-nscdc-battle-over-oil-pipelines/|archivedate=24 September 2014|df=}}</ref> The agency also involves in crisis resolutions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://prnigeria.com/2014/08/nscdc-hosts-peace-dialogue-in-north-east/|title=NSCDC Hosts Peace Dialogue in North-East|publisher=|accessdate=20 September 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140818165041/http://prnigeria.com/2014/08/nscdc-hosts-peace-dialogue-in-north-east/|archivedate=18 August 2014|df=}}</ref> They protect the country
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *http://www.nscdc.gov.ng/
{{Nigeria-law-stub}}

Wikipedia outlines are a special type of list article. They make up one of Wikipedia's content navigation systems
See [[Wikipedia:Outlines]] for more details. Further improvements to this outline are on the way ...--> {{See also|Index of Jordan-related articles}}[[Image:Jordan 2004 CIA map.jpg|thumb|Relief map of Jordan]] The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to Jordan:
'''[[Jordan]]''' – country located in [[Southwest Asia]], bordering [[Syria]] to the north, [[Iraq]] to the north-east, [[Israel]] and the [[Palestinian territories]] to the west, and [[Saudi Arabia]] to the east and south. It shares the coastlines of the [[Dead Sea]] with Israel and the [[Gulf of Aqaba]] with Israel, Saudi Arabia and [[Egypt]]. Jordan is a constitutional monarchy with representative government. The reigning monarch is the head of state, the chief executive and the commander-in-chief of the armed forces. The king exercises his executive authority through the prime ministers and the Council of Ministers, or cabinet. The cabinet, meanwhile, is responsible before the elected House of Deputies which, along with the House of Notables (Senate), constitutes the legislative branch of the government. The judicial branch is an independent branch of the government.
== Increasing Urbanization ==
Jordan‚Äôs population became significantly urbanized during the sixties, reaching a rate of urbanization of over 80% in 2011. This is due to Rural to urban migration, the arrival of refugees from Palestinian and Syria, and displaced persons who mostly settled in camps and services of UNRWA.<ref name="Atlas_of_jordan">{{cite web|url=https://books.openedition.org/ifpo/5021?lang=fr#tocfrom2n1|title=Altas_of_jordan|last=|first=|date=|website=Open Edition|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> {{TOC limit}}
==General reference== [[Image:Jo-map.png|thumb|A basic map of [[Jordan]]]] * [[International Phonetic Alphabet|Pronunciation]]:AL URDON * Common English country name: [[Jordan]] * Official English country name: The Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan * Common [[endonym]](s): [[List of countries and capitals in native languages| ]] * Official endonym(s): [[List of official endonyms of present-day nations and states| ]] * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Adjectival]](s): Jordanian * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Demonym]](s): * [[Etymology]]: [[Name of Jordan]] * [[International rankings of Jordan]] * [[ISO country codes]]: JO, JOR, 400 * [[ISO region codes]]: See [[ISO 3166-2:JO]] * [[Internet]] [[country code top-level domain]]: [[.jo]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=June 2013}}
'''Phillip Securities Indonesia''' is a [[financial services]] Based in [[Jakarta]], [[Indonesia]]. It is listed as a member of [[Indonesia Stock Exchange]] ([[Indonesian Stock Exchange|IDX]] - Code: [http://www.idx.co.id/en-us/home/brokers/profile/brokers.aspx KK]).
==Profile==
The company was officially registered as a member of [[Indonesia Stock Exchange]] in 1989.<ref>[http://www.idx.co.id/en-us/home/brokers/profile/brokers.aspx The Company Certificate in the Indonesia Stock Exchange]</ref> Based on IDX ([https://archive.is/20080416234051/http://www.idx.co.id/ Indonesia Stock Exchange]) data release about broker financial report 2012, company equity is more than IDR170 Billion.<ref>[http://www.idx.co.id/Portals/0/StaticData/Brokers/Financial_Report/2012/Audit/KK/Laporan%20Audit%20Konsolidasi%20PT%20Philip%20Securities%20%20Indonesia%2031%20Desember%202012.pdf Financial Report Audit 2012]</ref>
==Award==
In 2012, Indonesian Investor Magazine puts company ranking on 4th in the category of securities firms with assets above IDR 500 billion - 1 trillion after [http://www.kresnadirect.com Kresna Sekurindo Graha Tbk], [http://www.mncsecurities.com MNC Securities], [http://www.reliance-securities.com/ Reliance Securities Tbk] and followed by [http://www.utrade.co.id UOB Kay Hian Securities], [http://www.valburysecurities.co.id Valbury Securities], [http://www.lots.co.id Lautandhana Securindo] and [http://www.trimegah.com Trimegah Securities Tbk]. The award refers to a number of criteria. Among them, revenue growth, net income growth, NPM, ROA, and ROE.
==Research==
Phillip Securities Indonesia provides equity and market research for its brokerage clients. Its research division‚Äôs products include Daily Market Commentary, Company Focus, Afternoon Updates, Technical Recommendation, Regional Market Focus, Stock Screener, and Webinars.
'''Daily Market Commentaries''' are market reviews written in Bahasa Indonesia and in English. This report includes corporate and economic news. The feature is opened to the public.
'''Company Focus''' reports are ratings on stocks covered by its research analysts. The reports contain analysts‚Äô views of each covered stocks and their target fair values. The valuation method commonly found in these reports is the [[discounted cash flow]] method. This feature is only accessible to Phillip‚Äôs clients.
'''Afternoon Updates''' are short reports about stock trading activity in the first session. This feature is opened to the public.
'''Technical Recommendations''' contain stock recommendations with technical analysis. This feature is only available for Phillip‚Äôs clients.
'''Regional Market Focus''' contains compilations of market reviews and market news from various countries where Phillip Capital operates. This feature is only accessible to Phillip‚Äôs clients.
'''Stock Screener''' feature contains financial ratio screening module. Parameters and ratios provided include stock price, market capitalization, net profit, earnings per share, price to earnings ratio, book value, price to book value, debt to equity ratio, return on assets, return on equity, and profit margins of firms listed on the Indonesia Stock Exchange. This feature is only accessible to Phillip's clients.
'''The Webinars''' contains presentation slides and YouTube video links of the webinars held by Phillip's equity analysts. The webinars are provided free to the public.

revision.comment: assorted grammar, spelling, and link improvements
revision.text:
'''SMATV''' is Single Master Antenna Television (or Satellite Master Antenna Television),<ref name="ETSI"/> The purpose of SMATV is for supplying and controlling the number and type of channels to multiple televisions.<ref name="VIS"/> Not only TV channels but FM channels as well. It provides Reception of [[Direct broadcast satellite|DBS]] TV/FM channels for hotels, motels, dormitories, schools, hospitals and commercial properties with multiple tenants. Using a master antenna system video signals, audio signals and decoder signals can also be distributed.
It consists of single outdoor unit or antenna feeding to number of indoor units.<ref name="SCDR"/> The channels accessible are independent of other users. For maintaining a good [[Signal-to-noise_ratio|signal to noise ratio]] at all the indoor units served, a larger antenna is required, typically 2-3m in diameter.
A SMATV headend is used to receive and rebroadcast [[satellite TV]] channels throughout a property from a single satellite feed.<ref name="BaylinBerkoff1992"/>
The system consists of a master antenna and a matching transformer to match the balanced antenna with unbalanced cable and amplifiers.<ref name="TEDR"/> Most antennas have an impedance of around 300 Œ©. To convert it to 75 Œ©, a matching transformer (or [[balun]]) is used. For trunk line isolation, a resistive inductive device known as a [[Power_dividers_and_directional_couplers|splitter]] is used. The amplifier output is fed to the splitter through coaxial trunk lines.<ref name="EED"/>
There are several methods of distribution that are often used in a SMATV headend. These include: * [[IPTV]] ([[Internet Protocol]]) TV Systems<ref name="BroeckPierson2008"/> * COM1000 Pro:Idiom Encrypted HD Headend * [[L-Band]] Satellite TV Distribution<ref name="Long1999"/> There are two main approaches for distribution of digital TV signals in SMATV installations: * Transmodulation from satellite quaternary phase shift keying [[QPSK]] to quadrature amplitude modulation [[QAM]] * Direct distribution of [[QPSK]]<ref name="ETSI2"/>
In the United States, the satellite carriers providing the satellite TV signal for SMATV headend systems are: *[[DirecTV]] *[[Dish Network]] [http://www.onrip.com/smatv/ Smatv]
==References== {{reflist|refs= <ref name="ETSI">{{cite book|title=EN 300 473: "Digital Video Broadcasting (DVB); Satellite Master Antenna Television (SMATV) distribution systems"|url=http://www.etsi.org/deliver/etsi_en/300400_300499/300473/01.01.02_60/en_300473v010102p.pdf|isbn=2-7437-1655-X}}</ref>
<ref name="VIS">{{cite book|title=View Source vision and security: "Satellite Master Antenna Television System(S.M.A.T.V)|url=http://www.viewsecure.co.uk/smatv.php}}</ref>
<ref name="SCDR">{{cite book|author1=Dennis Roddy|title=Satellite Communications|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_Ef0N-ExWucC|accessdate=29 Nov 2014|isbn=978-0-07-007785-0|pages=569-}}</ref>
<ref name="BaylinBerkoff1992">{{cite book|author1=Frank Baylin|author2=Steve Berkoff|title=Wireless cable and SMATV|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xHfyAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=24 May 2013|date=August 1992|publisher=Baylin Publications|isbn=978-0-917893-17-9}}</ref>
<ref name="TEDR">{{cite book|author1=RG Gupta|title=Television Engineering and Video Systems|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P6BlcWaizHUC&pg=PT490|accessdate=29 Nov 2014|isbn=0-07-058596-2}}</ref>
<ref name="EED">{{cite book|author1=SK Bhattacharya|title=Electrical Engineering Drawing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gdsSXU4uF-MC&pg=PA239|accessdate=29 Nov 2014|isbn=81-224-0855-9}}</ref>
<ref name="BroeckPierson2008">{{cite book|author1=Wendy Van den Broeck|author2=J. Pierson|title=Digital television in Europe|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oc2HL71I7EgC&pg=PA241|accessdate=24 May 2013|year=2008|publisher=Asp / Vubpress / Upa|isbn=978-90-5487-541-3|pages=241‚Äì}}</ref>
<ref name="Long1999">{{cite book|author=Mark Long|title=Digital Satellite Television Handbook|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L4yQ0iztvQEC&pg=PA165|accessdate=24 May 2013|year=1999|publisher=Newnes|isbn=978-0-7506-7171-2|pages=165‚Äì}}</ref>
<ref name="ETSI2">{{cite book|title=EN 300 473 V1.1.2: "Digital Video Broadcasting (DVB); Satellite Master Antenna Television (SMATV) distribution systems"|url=http://www.etsi.org/deliver/etsi_en/300400_300499/300473/01.01.02_60/en_300473v010102p.pdf|isbn=2-7437-1655-X}} </ref>

{{Infobox single | Name = Salvem el m√≥n (Let's Save the World) | Artist = [[Anonymous (band)|Anonymous]] | Genre = [[Punk rock]] | Length = 2:58 | Writer = [[Niki Francesca]],
Guillem Gallego,
Alejandro Mart√≠nez | This single = "Salvem El M√≥n"
(2007) | Next single = "TBA" | Misc = {{Infobox song contest entry | embed=yes | song = {{flagicon|Andorra}} "Salvem el m√≥n" | image = | caption = | year = 2007 | country = Andorra | artist = [[Niki Francesca]],
Guillem Gallego,
Alejandro Mart√≠nez | as = [[Anonymous (band)|Anonymous]] | with = | language = | languages = [[Catalan language|Catalan]], [[English language|English]] | composer = [[Niki Francesca]],
Guillem Gallego,
Alejandro Mart√≠nez | lyricist = [[Niki Francesca]],
Guillem Gallego,
Alejandro Mart√≠nez | place = | points = | place_semi = 12th | points_semi = 80 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?2007ad from Diggiloo Thrush] | prev = Sense tu | prev_link = Sense tu | next = Casanova | next_link = Casanova (Gisela song) }} }} "'''Salvem el m√≥n'''" ("Let's save the world") was the [[Andorra]]n entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2007]], performed in [[Catalan language|Catalan]] and English by [[Anonymous (band)|Anonymous]]. This was the first Andorran entry not to feature monolingual Catalan lyrics and not to be performed by a female soloist, with all the members of the band being male. [[Image:ESC 2007 Andorra - Anonymous - Salvem el mon.jpg|200px|thumb|left|[[Anonymous (band)|Anonymous]] performing "Salvem el m√≥n" for [[Andorra]].]] The song is a [[pop punk]] number, the first such song ever to be performed at the Contest. Lead singer "N!ki" sings about his disbelief at the state of the world, remarking that "The world is in danger and you don't do anything". He sings that this is because everyone is only interested in their own lives, and is unwilling to do anything for the greater good. Thus, he proposes that everyone unite and think about things they can do to improve the world. The chorus is delivered in English, with the band singing that humanity as a whole has treated the world badly, having "turned [it] upside down". The theme of a call to action was made more explicit in the performance, with N!ki calling out "Thank you! We can still save the world!" after the song was finished. As Andorra had not previously qualified for the final, the song was performed in the semi-final. Here, it was performed twenty-first (following [[Malta]]'s [[Olivia Lewis]] with "[[Vertigo (Eurovision song)|Vertigo]]" and preceding [[Hungary]]'s [[Magdi R√∫zsa]] with "[[Unsubstantial Blues]]"). At the close of voting, it had received 80 points, placing 12th in the 28-strong field and thus missing out on qualifying for the final by two places. This was, however, Andorra's best result - with their entry in 2006 coming last in the semi-final, for example. Following the Contest, the song charted at number 3 in the [[Spain|Spanish]] chart. ==References== *{{cite web|url=http://www.diggiloo.net/?2007ad|title=2007 Andorra|author=Diggiloo Thrush|accessdate=2007-06-10}} *{{cite web|url=http://www.freewebs.com/anonymouspunkrock/|title=Fan home page|accessdate=2007-06-15}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 2007}} {{Andorra in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Salvem El Mon}} [[Category:Eurovision songs of Andorra]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of 2007]] [[Category:Multilingual songs]] [[Category:2007 songs]] {{2000s-song-stub}} {{Andorra-stub}} {{Eurovision-stub}}

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=October 2018}} [[File:The Earthbound.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The Earthbound, 2008.]] '''The Earthbound''' is a [[Greece|Greek]] band.
The band was formed in [[Athens]] in 1998 by six members and former members of [[The Last Drive]], [[Honeydive]], [[Rockin' Bones]] and [[Engine-V]], which includes Alexis Kalofolias and Thanos Amorginos.<ref name="mic-gr">{{cite web |title=Earthbound la guerra final |url=http://www.mic.gr/record-review/earthbound-la-guerra-final |website=Mic.gr |accessdate=20 October 2018}}</ref> After playing locally for about a year, including a slot in Rockwave festival in 1999, the Earthbound recorded its debut 7" single "The Valley/Riverside Song/Tercera Cancion", released with ''Fractal Press'' magazine.
The Earthbound signed to [[Trade Records]] and recorded their self-titled debut album produced by their sound-engineer, Jim Spliff. It was released in 2000 and featured 13 songs, including three covers of songs by [[Kyuss]], [[Woody Guthrie]] and Guillermo Portaballes that showcased the band's diverse influences. {{citation needed|date=October 2018}}
In 2001, they recorded the soundtrack for the film ''Stakaman'' by Antonis Kafetzopoulos, which was released by M Records. At the same period, Alex K and Thanos A worked on the soundtrack for the film SOSE ME (directed by Stratos Tzitzis), released a few months later by Universal (Greece). The Earthbound spent the next eighteen months touring. They also took part in two benefit concerts for the campaign Escuelas para Chiapas (A School for Chiapas) and in June 2003 they played at the demonstration against the EU summit in Thessaloniki. In September 2003 Louis (former member of the historical Athenian punk band ''Stress'') joined on trumpet and percussion.
In 2004, they signed to Sirius (the record label formed by Manos Hadjidakis) and started working on their third album, ''Brotherhood of the Dog'', this time produced by Jim Spliff and the band itself. The album was released later the same year and featured 11 songs (including an Ennio Morricone cover).
In early 2005, they played two gigs in Cyprus and recruited a second trumpet player, Johnny Mato (also member of Dr. Vodkatini and Da Traces).The eight-piece band contributed a track to the [[Spinalonga records]] compilation In The Junkyard vol. II and continued touring and writing songs for their next album.
It was finally released in spring of 2008 at the band's own label, LAB Records, under the title ''La Guerra Final'' . Including 11 original songs, it is considered by many their best studio effort.
The Earthbound suspended action in summer of 2009.
==Discography== * La Guerra Final (2008), Lab Records, produced by Jim Spliff and Thanos Amorginos * Brotherhood Of The Dog (2004), Sirius Records M41 / CD, produced by Jim Spliff & The Earthbound *Stakaman O.S.T. (2001), M Records, produced by Jim Spliff & The Earthbound *The Earthbound (2000), Trade Records, produced by Jim Spliff, co-produced by Aris Christou *The Earthbound (1999), Underworld D-Tales/ 7'', produced by Jim Spliff & The Earthbound
==References== <references />
==External links== * [http://www.theearthbound.com/en/Default.asp?area=bio The Earthbound Biography - Official site]
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Earthbound, The}} [[Category:Greek rock music groups]] [[Category:Musical groups from Athens]]
