{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} [[File:WWVH antenna field.jpg|thumb|right|300px|WWVH antenna field]] '''WWVH''' is the callsign of the U.S. [[National Institute of Standards and Technology]]'s [[shortwave]] [[radio]] [[time signal]] station in [[Kekaha, Hawaii|Kekaha]], on the island of [[Kauai]] in the state of [[Hawaii]]. {{Coord|21|59|16|N|159|45|47|W|type:landmark_region:US-HI|display=title}} WWVH is the Pacific sister station to [[WWV (radio station)|WWV]], and has a similar broadcast format. Like WWV, WWVH's main function is the dissemination of official U.S. Government time, through exactly the same methods as found on WWV's signal. To minimize interference with the WWV broadcasts on the same frequencies, WWVH's broadcasts on 5, 10 and 15 MHz are directional, pointed primarily west. Despite this strategy, in certain places, particularly on the west coast of North America; and at certain times, due to [[ionosphere|ionospheric]] conditions, the listener can actually hear both WWV and WWVH on the same frequency at the same time. The information modulated on the carrier is modified to reduce confusion if both are received simultaneously. In particular, voice announcements on one correspond to silent periods on the other. WWVH uses a female voice to distinguish itself from WWV, which uses a male voice. WWVH time signals can also be accessed by telephone. {| class="wikitable" |+ NIST Time Signal Station Services ! Station ! Date in service ! Date out of service ! Radio frequencies ! Audio frequencies ! Musical pitch ! Time intervals ! Time signals ! UT2 correction ! Propagation forecasts ! Geophysical alerts |- | WWV | 1923 | rowspan="3" | | '''‚úî''' | '''‚úî''' | '''‚úî''' | '''‚úî''' | '''‚úî''' | '''‚úî''' | '''‚úî''' | '''‚úî''' |- | WWVH | 1948 | '''‚úî''' | '''‚úî''' | '''‚úî''' | '''‚úî''' | '''‚úî''' | '''‚úî''' | | '''‚úî''' |- | WWVB | 1963 | '''‚úî''' | | | '''‚úî''' | '''‚úî''' | '''‚úî''' | | |- | WWVL | 1963 | 1972 | '''‚úî''' | | | | | | | |} == Transmission system ==
{| class="wikitable" ! colspan=2 | WWVH antenna coordinates |- | 2.5 MHz || {{Coord|21|59|20.9|N|159|45|52.4|W|type:landmark_region:US-HI}} |- | 5 MHz || {{Coord|21|59|10.8|N|159|45|44.8|W|type:landmark_region:US-HI}} |- | 10 MHz || {{Coord|21|59|18.2|N|159|45|51.3|W|type:landmark_region:US-HI}} |- | 15 MHz || {{Coord|21|59|15.3|N|159|45|50.0|W|type:landmark_region:US-HI}} |}
WWVH broadcasts its signal on four transmitters, one for each frequency. The 2.5 MHz transmitter puts out an [[Effective radiated power|ERP]] of 5 kW, while the other transmitters use 10 kW of ERP. The 2.5 MHz antenna is one half-[[wavelength]] tall, and radiates in an omnidirectional pattern. The remaining antennas each consist of two elements one half-wavelength tall and horizontally separated by one quarter-wavelength. The signal radiating from one element is in [[quadrature phase]] with respect to the signal from the other. This results in a [[cardioid]] radiation pattern with a maximum gain directed west. {{clear|right}} == Broadcast format == {{Main|WWV (radio station)#Broadcast format|l1=WWV (radio station)‚ÄîBroadcast format}} [[File:WWVH recording - 20150316.ogg|thumb|Recording of WWVH from 4:58:43 to 5:03:08 UTC on March 16, 2015.]] [[File:WWV-WWVH time code format.svg|750px|center]] The WWVH signal is extremely similar to the WWV signal, but some changes have been made to reduce confusion if both are heard at once:{{cite book|last=Nelson|first=Glenn|author2=Michael Lombardi|author3=Dean Okayama|title=NIST Special Publication 250-67: NIST Time and Frequency Stations: WWV, WWVH and WWVB|publisher=NIST|year=2005|url=http://tf.nist.gov/timefreq/general/pdf/1969.pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170125154929/http://tf.nist.gov/timefreq/general/pdf/1969.pdf|archivedate=January 25, 2017|df=mdy-all|access-date=January 26, 2017}} * The 5 ms second ticks are 6 cycles of [[Media:1200 Hz.ogg|1,200 Hz]] rather than 5 cycles of 1,000 Hz. The 800 ms minute beep is also 1,200 Hz. (Like WWV, this is omitted during minutes 29 and 59, and changed to 1,500 Hz at the top of each hour.) * The voice announcements use a female voice (that of [[Jane Barbe]]) and last 7.5 seconds starting 15 seconds before the minute. (WWV broadcasts in a male voice during the last 7.5 seconds of each minute.) * The audio tones sent during the first 45 seconds of most minutes are swapped: [[Media:600 Hz.ogg|600 Hz]] is played during even minutes, and [[Media:500 Hz.ogg|500 Hz]] is played during odd minutes. (Receiving both simultaneously gives the listener a sound similar to a continuously-ringing chime.) * The [[A440 (Concert A)|A440]] tone marking the hour is sent during minute 1 (as opposed to minute 2 for WWV). Like WWV, it is omitted during the first hour of each UTC day. * The audio tones are suppressed while WWV is transmitting voice announcements: minutes 00, 08‚Äì10, 14‚Äì19, and 30. * The voice announcements are rescheduled relative to WWV: ** Station identification is made during minutes 29 and 59 (vs. 00 and 30) ** [[Notice Advisory to NAVSTAR Users|GPS satellite health reports]] are transmitted during minutes 43 and 44 (vs. 14 and 15) ** [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|NOAA]] space weather geoalerts are transmitted during minute 45 (vs. 18) ** [[National Weather Service]] storm warnings for all sections of the Pacific Ocean are broadcast during minutes 48‚Äì51, overflowing to minute 52 when necessary (vs. Atlantic and northeast Pacific information during 08‚Äì10 and 11). ** Minutes 03 and 47 are used for NIST special announcements when necessary (vs. 04 and 16). Like WWV, prior to the [[Omega (navigation system)|OMEGA]] Navigation System shutdown in 1997, the OMEGA status report was broadcast at :47 past the hour. == Half-hourly station identification announcement == WWVH identifies itself twice each hour, at 29 and 59 minutes past the hour. The text of the identification is as follows: {{cquote|National Institute of Standards and Technology Time. This is radio station WWVH, Kauai, Hawaii, broadcasting on internationally allocated standard carrier frequencies of 2.5, 5, 10 and 15 megahertz, providing time of day, standard time interval, and other related information. Inquiries regarding these transmissions may be directed to the National Institute of Standards and Technology, Radio Station WWVH, [[Post Office Box]] 417, [[Kekaha, Hawaii]] 96752. [[Aloha]].}} Reception reports sent to that address will on request be answered with a [[QSL card]].[http://tf.nist.gov/stations/qsl.htm QSL Gallery for NIST Radio Stations] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170911050255/http://tf.nist.gov/stations/qsl.htm |date=September 11, 2017 }} == Telephone service == WWVH's time signal can also be accessed by calling +1(808)335-4363. == References == {{reflist}} == See also == * [[Radio clock]] ‚Äì time-signal receivers * [[WWVB]] ‚Äì longwave time broadcast station * [[WWV (radio station)|WWV]] ‚Äì Colorado shortwave time broadcast station == External links == {{GeoGroupTemplate}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20150622210605/https://soundcloud.com/shortwavemusic/sets/at-the-tone-a-little-history] {{TimeSig}} {{Time signal Authorities}} {{US Shortwave Radio}} [[Category:National Institute of Standards and Technology]] [[Category:Kauai County, Hawaii]] [[Category:Time in the United States]] [[Category:Shortwave radio stations in the United States]] [[Category:Time signal radio stations]] [[de:WWV (Zeitzeichensender)#Kurzwellensender WWVH auf Hawaii]]

[[siSwati]] |budget = }} '''''Without the King''''' is a [[2007 in film|2007]] [[documentary film]] by Michael Skolnik, an [[United States|American]] [[filmmaker]]. It follows problems of [[Swaziland]], a [[landlocked country]] in [[southern Africa]].{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/06/world/africa/06king.html?pagewanted=all | work=The New York Times | first=Barry | last=Bearak | title=In Destitute Swaziland, Leader Lives Royally | date=2008-09-06}}{{cite web |url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117936887.html?categoryid=31&cs=1 |title=Without the King |date=April 23, 2008 |last=Scheib |first=Ronnie |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |accessdate=May 3, 2014}} The film features [[Mswati III of Swaziland|Mswati III]], the king of Swaziland, and his heiress and self claimed [[rapper]] [[Princess Sikhanyiso]].{{cite news|author=Ronnie Scheib |url=https://variety.com/2008/film/reviews/without-the-king-1200523027/# |title=Without the King |publisher=Variety |date=2008-04-23 |accessdate=2013-11-27}} It shows the angry populace and the country's problems such as a high [[HIV]] prevalence, comparing it with the daily life of Mswati III, [[Africa]]'s last [[absolute monarch]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/25/movies/25king.html?ref=mswatiiii&_r=0|title=Without the King (2007)|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2013-11-27|first=Jeannette|last=Catsoulis|date=2008-04-25}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nysun.com/arts/swazilands-king-of-pain/75347/ |title=Swaziland's King of Pain - The New York Sun |publisher=Nysun.com |date=2008-04-25 |accessdate=2014-05-14}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|id=0997233|title=Without the King}} *[https://movies.nytimes.com/2008/04/25/movies/25king.html An Extravagant Ruler of a Modest Kingdom - ''New York Times'' Movie review] {{DEFAULTSORT:Without the King}} [[Category:2007 films]] [[Category:Documentary films about royalty]] [[Category:2000s documentary films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American documentary films]] [[Category:Films set in Eswatini]] [[Category:Politics of Eswatini]] {{bio-documentary-film-stub}} {{Swaziland-stub}}
